Definition: Application Programming Interface - A set of protocols and tools for building software applications that specify how software components should interact
Representational State Transfer - An architectural style for designing networked applications using HTTP requests to access and manipulate data
Continuous Integration/Continuous Deployment - Development practices that automate building, testing, and deploying code changes
JSON Web Token - A compact, URL-safe token format used for securely transmitting information between parties as a JSON object
Open Authorization - An open standard for access delegation, commonly used for token-based authentication
Domain Name System - The hierarchical naming system that translates human-readable domain names into IP addresses
Hypertext Transfer Protocol Secure - An encrypted version of HTTP that uses TLS/SSL for secure communication
Structured Query Language - A programming language used to manage and manipulate relational databases
Non-relational database systems designed for distributed data stores with flexible schemas and horizontal scaling
Secure Shell - A cryptographic network protocol for secure remote login and command execution over an unsecured network
Virtual Private Network - A technology that creates a secure, encrypted connection over a less secure network
Internet of Things - A network of physical devices embedded with sensors and software that connect and exchange data
Content Delivery Network - A geographically distributed group of servers that work together to provide fast delivery of internet content
Cross-Origin Resource Sharing - A security feature that allows or restricts web applications from making requests to different domains
A communication protocol that provides full-duplex communication channels over a single TCP connection
Create, Read, Update, Delete - The four basic operations for persistent storage in database applications
Multi-Factor Authentication - A security system requiring multiple methods of authentication to verify user identity
Software Development Kit - A collection of software tools and libraries used to develop applications for specific platforms
Integrated Development Environment - A software application providing comprehensive facilities for software development
Development Operations - A set of practices combining software development and IT operations to shorten development cycles
Supervisory Control and Data Acquisition - A control system architecture used for high-level process supervisory management in industrial facilities
Programmable Logic Controller - An industrial computer used to automate manufacturing processes and machinery control
Human-Machine Interface - A user interface that connects an operator to the controller for industrial equipment
Building Management System - A computer-based control system that monitors and manages mechanical and electrical equipment in buildings
Heating, Ventilation, and Air Conditioning - Technology for indoor environmental comfort through thermal regulation and air quality
Air Handling Unit - A device used to regulate and circulate air as part of an HVAC system
Variable Air Volume - An HVAC system that varies the airflow at a constant temperature to meet zone requirements
Fan Coil Unit - A simple device consisting of a heating/cooling coil and a fan used for temperature control
Variable Frequency Drive - A motor controller that drives an electric motor by varying the frequency and voltage of its power supply
Remote Terminal Unit - A microprocessor-controlled electronic device that interfaces sensors to SCADA systems
Distributed Control System - A computerized control system for industrial processes with distributed control elements
Piping and Instrumentation Diagram - A detailed diagram showing process equipment, instrumentation, and piping
Computer-Aided Design - Software used to create precision drawings or technical illustrations
Building Information Modeling - A digital representation of physical and functional characteristics of a building
Mechanical, Electrical, and Plumbing - Core building systems that ensure functionality and occupant comfort
Energy Management System - A system of computer-aided tools to monitor, control, and optimize energy consumption
Outside Air Temperature - The temperature of the outdoor ambient air measured for HVAC control purposes
Supply Air Temperature - The temperature of air leaving an air handling unit or cooling/heating coil
Return Air Temperature - The temperature of air returning to the air handling unit from conditioned spaces
Mixed Air Temperature - The temperature of the mixture of return air and outside air in an HVAC system
Differential Pressure - The difference in pressure between two points, used for monitoring filters and airflow
Cubic Feet per Minute - A measurement of airflow volume used in HVAC system design and operation
British Thermal Unit - A unit of heat energy commonly used to measure heating and cooling capacity
Kilowatt - A unit of electrical power equal to 1000 watts, used to measure energy consumption
Parts Per Million - A unit of measurement for concentration, commonly used for air quality and water quality monitoring
Service Level Agreement - A contract defining the level of service expected from a service provider
Key Performance Indicator - A measurable value that demonstrates how effectively objectives are being achieved
Return on Investment - A performance measure used to evaluate the efficiency or profitability of an investment
Request for Proposal - A document soliciting proposals from potential vendors for a product or service
Request for Quotation - A document requesting suppliers to submit price quotes for specific products or services
Statement of Work - A document defining project-specific activities, deliverables, and timelines
Proof of Concept - A demonstration that verifies certain concepts or theories have practical potential
Minimum Viable Product - A product with enough features to attract early adopters and validate a product idea
User Acceptance Testing - Testing performed by end users to verify that a system meets requirements
Quality Assurance - A systematic process to ensure products or services meet specified requirements
Standard Operating Procedure - A set of step-by-step instructions for routine operations
Estimated Time of Arrival - The expected time when a shipment, task, or project will be completed
End of Day - A deadline reference typically meaning the close of business hours
For Your Information - Used to share information without requiring action from the recipient
To Be Determined - Indicates that a decision or specification has not yet been finalized
Not Applicable - Indicates that something does not apply to a particular situation
As Soon As Possible - Indicates urgency in completing a task or delivering information
Work in Progress - Tasks or projects that have been started but not yet completed
Factory Acceptance Test - Testing performed at the manufacturer's facility before shipping equipment
Site Acceptance Test - Testing performed at the installation site to verify system functionality
Operations and Maintenance - Ongoing activities required to keep systems and facilities running efficiently
Preventive Maintenance - Regular maintenance performed to prevent equipment failure and extend lifespan
Mean Time Between Failures - Average time between system failures, used to measure reliability
Mean Time To Repair - Average time required to repair a failed system or component
Root Cause Analysis - A method of problem solving used to identify the underlying causes of faults or problems
Failure Mode and Effects Analysis - A systematic approach for identifying potential failure modes and their effects
International Organization for Standardization - An international body that develops and publishes standards
Occupational Safety and Health Administration - US agency ensuring safe and healthy working conditions
Personal Protective Equipment - Equipment worn to minimize exposure to workplace hazards
Lockout/Tagout - Safety procedure to ensure dangerous machines are properly shut off during maintenance
